Award.AwardTitle: A Bio-Inspired Strategy for In-Plane Energy Dissipation through Suture Interfaces

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research will explore a new strategy for the creation of mechanically sound connections between individual parts of plates and shells. This approach is inspired by findings in natural materials where individual parts are often found to be connected to each other om jigsaw-puzzle-like structure. One such example are seed coats of some plants, which consist of stiff, nominally planar building blocks that are connected to one another via compliant zigzag seams. These seams are called suture interfaces. This investigation will focus on how the network of suture interfaces contributes to toughness, damage-tolerance, and the efficiency of load transmission between building blocks. Engineering analysis, computer simulations and experiments on 3D printed plate and shell systems will be conducted. The knowledge gained from this research will provide guidelines for designing new lightweight and damage-tolerant material systems with broad engineering applications in aerospace, naval, architectural structures, ground vehicles, and armor. The interdisciplinary nature of the research will involve diversified participants and will expose students to the areas of mechanics, materials, biology and manufacturing.

The research will employ an integrated analytical, computational and experimental methodology to systematically quantify the mechano-morphological effects in the bio-inspired jigsaw composite plates and shells. A hybrid analytical and finite element modeling approach will be used to predict the mechanical behaviors of suture interfaces and jigsaw composites, including the mixed-mode damage initiation and evolution, two basic failure mechanisms of suture interfaces and the failure mechanism transition. A 3D multi-material printer will be extensively used to fabricate suture and composite specimens for mechanical experiments to verify or provide inputs to the analytical and numerical models. In the area of bio-inspired engineering, although substantial progress has been made on understanding the mechanical response of biological structures, the manufacture of artificial composites with precisely-controlled interface morphology and material composition remains a challenging goal. The development of 3D printing technology provides an opportunity to overcome this difficulty. Therefore, this research will not only explore a new toughening and energy-dissipation mechanisms of a natural composite material but also the methodology developed reveals a paradigm for using 3D printing as a tool to explore fundamental engineering and scientific questions and new concepts in biomimetic design.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research is inspired by natural materials with a jigsaw-puzzle-like micro-structure, such as the seed coats of some plant species, such as succulents and grasses including the purslanes (Portulaca spp.) and millets (Panicum spp.). A new bio-inspired strategy was explored for energy dissipation through the network of suture interfaces in the plane of composite plates and shells. Through this project, the relationship between the morphological attributes, mechanical properties and functions in the seedcoat’s unique microstructure were well understood. Biomimetic prototypes were designed and fabricated via multi-material 3D printing, and mechanical experiments and finite element simulations were performed on the scaled-up specimens. Comprehensive design guidelines for this new category of bio-inspired architectured materials were developed.

   The results show that the waviness of the sutural tessellation plays a key role (even more important than the volume fraction of each phase) in governing the mechanical response. Generally, when the sutural tessellations become wavier, an applied load can be more effectively transferred through the softer wavy interface to the hard phase, and therefore both overall strength and fracture toughness can increase. It was also found that when the stiffness ratio between the hard and soft phases increases, the contribution of the suture waviness to the overall mechanical performance becomes even more important. Remarkably, when the stiffness ratio between the soft and hard phase and the waviness increases beyond a certain range, the suture tessellations exhibit a negative Poisson’s ratio. Also, new material models were developed to capture the visco-hyperelastic behavior and damage initiation and propagation in the 3D printed soft interfacial layer, as enables quantification of the mechanical properties and behavior of 3D printed biomimetic designs via numerical simulations.  

   This new bio-inspired design concept with sutural tessellations opens a new avenue of research through effectively tailoring the waviness of the suture lines to achieve mechanical properties beyond those found in traditional composite plates. It also provides an alternative roadmap for the development of new functionally graded composites for effective protection and energy dissipation. The knowledge gained from this research provides guidelines for designing new lightweight and damage-tolerant materials with broad engineering applications in aerospace, naval, architectural structures, ground vehicles, and armor. The interdisciplinary nature of the research involved diversified participants and exposed students at all different levels to the areas of mechanics, materials, biology and additive manufacturing.

   In addition, as demonstrated by the current study, technological advances in multi-material 3D printing have enabled the fast and accurate fabrication of composite architectures with complicated geometries and material combinations for the quantitative evaluation of novel design concepts. Therefore, the methodology developed reveals a paradigm for using 3D printing as a tool to explore fundamental engineering and scientific questions and new concepts in biomimetic design.

  

 


Last Modified: 10/18/2018
Modified by: Yaning Li
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This research is inspired by natural materials with a jigsaw-puzzle-like micro-structure, such as the seed coats of some plant species, such as succulents and grasses including the purslanes (Portulaca spp.) and millets (Panicum spp.). A new bio-inspired strategy was explored for energy dissipation through the network of suture interfaces in the plane of composite plates and shells. Through this project, the relationship between the morphological attributes, mechanical properties and functions in the seedcoat?s unique microstructure were well understood. Biomimetic prototypes were designed and fabricated via multi-material 3D printing, and mechanical experiments and finite element simulations were performed on the scaled-up specimens. Comprehensive design guidelines for this new category of bio-inspired architectured materials were developed. The results show that the waviness of the sutural tessellation plays a key role (even more important than the volume fraction of each phase) in governing the mechanical response. Generally, when the sutural tessellations become wavier, an applied load can be more effectively transferred through the softer wavy interface to the hard phase, and therefore both overall strength and fracture toughness can increase. It was also found that when the stiffness ratio between the hard and soft phases increases, the contribution of the suture waviness to the overall mechanical performance becomes even more important. Remarkably, when the stiffness ratio between the soft and hard phase and the waviness increases beyond a certain range, the suture tessellations exhibit a negative Poisson?s ratio. Also, new material models were developed to capture the visco-hyperelastic behavior and damage initiation and propagation in the 3D printed soft interfacial layer, as enables quantification of the mechanical properties and behavior of 3D printed biomimetic designs via numerical simulations. This new bio-inspired design concept with sutural tessellations opens a new avenue of research through effectively tailoring the waviness of the suture lines to achieve mechanical properties beyond those found in traditional composite plates. It also provides an alternative roadmap for the development of new functionally graded composites for effective protection and energy dissipation. The knowledge gained from this research provides guidelines for designing new lightweight and damage-tolerant materials with broad engineering applications in aerospace, naval, architectural structures, ground vehicles, and armor. The interdisciplinary nature of the research involved diversified participants and exposed students at all different levels to the areas of mechanics, materials, biology and additive manufacturing. In addition, as demonstrated by the current study, technological advances in multi-material 3D printing have enabled the fast and accurate fabrication of composite architectures with complicated geometries and material combinations for the quantitative evaluation of novel design concepts. Therefore, the methodology developed reveals a paradigm for using 3D printing as a tool to explore fundamental engineering and scientific questions and new concepts in biomimetic design.
